conclusion: Determine the magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the metal rod MN and the resistance value of R2.
The total resistance in the circuit is the sum of the resistance of the metal rod R1, the resistance of the sliding rheostat R2, and the internal resistance r of the power source.
Given: R1 = 4 Ω, r = 1 Ω, E = V_total = 10 V.
Using Ohm's law, I = 10 V / (5 Ω + R2).
The magnetic force FB on the metal rod is given by FB = B I L sin θ.
Given: B = 0.6 T, θ = 30°.
The length L of the rod perpendicular to the magnetic field is the horizontal component of the rod's length, calculated using trigonometry.
Given: d = 15 cm = 0.15 m, θ = 30°.
Substitute L into the magnetic force equation: FB = 0.039 N × I.
For the metal rod to remain stationary, the magnetic force must balance the gravitational force acting on the rod.
The gravitational force Fg is given by Fg = m g.
Given: m = 17 g = 0.017 kg, g = 10 m/s².
At equilibrium, FB = Fg, 0.039 N × I = 0.17 N.
Solving for I: I ≈ 4.36 A.
Substitute I back into the expression for the total current: 4.36 A = 10 V / (5 Ω + R2).
Solving for R2: R2 ≈ 2.7 Ω.
The magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the metal rod is approximately 0.039 N.
The resistance value of R2 is approximately 2.7 Ω.
